questions.text: Clear explanations of drama concepts are more important than using specialist terminology.
questions.explanation: The ability to respond using sophisticated, accurate, and detailed drama terminology was the distinguishing feature of high-scoring responses. Develop a glossary of key terms.
questions.studyTip: Build a glossary. Practice using precise drama language.

questions.text: High-scoring responses consistently use sophisticated, accurate drama terminology throughout.
questions.explanation: Practise using appropriate terminology to explain how actors apply expressive and performance skills in various styles and how they use production areas.
questions.studyTip: Drama terms show drama thinking. The right word matters.

concepts.title: Distinguish performance skills from dramatic elements

questions.text: Performance skills and dramatic elements can be discussed interchangeably when analysing drama.
questions.explanation: Common errors related to students not understanding terminology and applying the wrong skill or element. Know the difference between performance skills and dramatic elements.
questions.studyTip: Performance skills: what actors DO. Dramatic elements: what's CREATED.

questions.text: Performance skills (focus, energy, timing) are distinct from dramatic elements (mood, contrast, tension, rhythm, conflict).
questions.explanation: Revise all key terminology, particularly the differences between performance skills and dramatic elements. Using the wrong category costs marks.
questions.studyTip: Make two lists. Know which is which. Don't mix them up.

questions.text: Discussing what the character does demonstrates understanding of the performance.
questions.explanation: A common error was students appearing to confuse the actor with the character. You must discuss what the ACTOR does to create the character, not what the character does.
questions.studyTip: Actor = the person. Character = the role. Discuss the actor's choices.

questions.text: Analysis must focus on what the ACTOR does to create the character, not what the character does in the story.
questions.explanation: Write about how the actor uses skills and techniques. 'Max Brown applied focus when...' not 'Knock looked at the spider when...'
questions.studyTip: Actor's name + their skill + how they applied it. That's the formula.

questions.text: Describing what happened in a performance demonstrates analytical skill.
questions.explanation: Students often described rather than analysed, and therefore didn't properly explore the intended effect that an actor was trying to create. Analysis requires WHY and HOW.
questions.studyTip: Not just WHAT happened, but WHY the actor chose it and WHAT effect.

questions.text: Analysis must explore the intended effect the actor was trying to create, not just describe what happened.
questions.explanation: Identify how and why actors did what they were doing and link it directly to how they wanted the audience to experience the moment.
questions.studyTip: What did the actor do? Why? What effect on audience? All three.

questions.text: Adding an evaluative statement at the end of your response shows you can evaluate.
questions.explanation: The most important area for improvement is to apply a range of evaluative terms THROUGHOUT the response rather than tacking them on at the end.
questions.studyTip: Evaluation woven through, not added at the end.

questions.text: Evaluative language must be embedded throughout your response, not just added at the conclusion.
questions.explanation: Use evaluative terms throughout: 'expertly manipulated,' 'successfully created,' 'effectively established.' A single word at the end is insufficient.
questions.studyTip: Every paragraph should have evaluative adjectives. Not just the last line.

concepts.title: Use evaluative language for actors' skills

questions.text: Describing how skills were applied is sufficient for evaluation questions.
questions.explanation: Practise evaluation skills using evaluative language that conveys an actor's ability to apply expressive and performance skills to communicate mood, contrast, tension, rhythm, and conflict.
questions.studyTip: Not 'the actor used' but 'the actor expertly/successfully/effectively used.'

questions.text: Evaluative language should convey judgement about how well actors applied skills to create dramatic effects.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses support judgments with evidence from performance: 'Brown successfully created significant contrast... thereby communicating well to the audience...'
questions.studyTip: Make a judgement. Support it with evidence. That's evaluation.

questions.text: Referring to characters by name is sufficient for discussing playlist plays.
questions.explanation: Learn the names of actors and creatives in the playlisted play you have studied. You need to discuss actors by name, not just their characters.
questions.studyTip: Actor names, not just character names. Learn who played who.

questions.text: You must learn the names of actors and creatives from your playlist play to discuss their work specifically.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses reference actors by name: 'Max Brown applied focus when...' This shows you're analysing the performer's craft, not just the story.
questions.studyTip: Make a cast list. Know every actor's name and their character(s).

questions.text: General references to the play demonstrate overall understanding.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring responses didn't give a specific moment in the play which illustrated the skill being discussed. You must identify clear, specific moments.
questions.studyTip: Name the specific moment. 'In the battle scene when...' not 'throughout the play...'

questions.text: Responses must identify specific moments from the play to illustrate how actors applied skills.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses were articulate about the moments in the play they were discussing and how the actor impacted the audience each time.
questions.studyTip: Specific scene + specific actor + specific skill + specific effect.

questions.text: Actor-audience relationship refers to how characters relate to each other.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring responses demonstrated confusion about actor-audience relationship, focusing on personal relationships rather than the requirements of actor-audience relationship as a performance skill.
questions.studyTip: Actor-audience = how performer connects with viewers. Not character relationships.

questions.text: Actor-audience relationship is a performance skill describing how the performer connects with and affects the audience.
questions.explanation: Discuss how the actor established and manipulated their connection with the audience—creating mood, eliciting responses, breaking the fourth wall, etc.
questions.studyTip: How did the actor make the audience feel? That's actor-audience relationship.

questions.text: Identifying which production areas were used demonstrates understanding.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses made clear how the production area was being manipulated or interacted with in the performance. Simply identifying it isn't enough.
questions.studyTip: Not just 'lighting was used' but 'the actor responded to the lighting by...'

questions.text: Explain how the actor manipulated or interacted with production areas to create meaning.
questions.explanation: For lighting or sound design, explain how the actor responded to or performed with this production area. Show the actor's active engagement with technical elements.
questions.studyTip: What did the actor DO with the production area? How did it create meaning?

questions.text: Describing the imagined performance demonstrates understanding of devising.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring responses described a moment in performance rather than its development. Practise describing the processes of devising an ensemble as opposed to performing to an audience.
questions.studyTip: Devising = how you CREATE it. Performing = how you SHOW it. Different.

questions.text: When asked about devising, describe development processes, not how the final performance would look.
questions.explanation: Higher-scoring responses anchored their answers in the rehearsal room, either naming improvisation activities or referring to the general activity of improvising.
questions.studyTip: Stay in the rehearsal room. What activities? What exploration? Not the final show.

questions.text: Describing interesting ideas from stimulus images shows creative thinking.
questions.explanation: Students who identified an idea but did not relate it directly to one or more of the images could not be awarded full marks. Always connect ideas to specific stimulus.
questions.studyTip: Idea must connect to image. 'This image inspired...' Make the link explicit.

questions.text: Ideas must be directly connected to specific stimulus material with the dramatic potential clearly explained.
questions.explanation: Make it clear whether it's a story, idea, or theme being explored and how the stimulus provides dramatic potential. Reference specific images.
questions.studyTip: Which image? What's the idea? Where's the dramatic potential? All three.

questions.text: Identifying one expressive skill for each character demonstrates brainstorming.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring responses just listed one expressive skill appropriate to the character without considering how it might be applied. Brainstorming requires multiple possibilities.
questions.studyTip: Brainstorm = many options. Not one idea per character.

questions.text: Brainstorming requires exploring multiple possibilities for how expressive skills might develop each character.
questions.explanation: Higher-scoring responses explored multiple possibilities to link expressive skills to characters. Show range of thinking, not just one idea per box.
questions.studyTip: Many ideas, not just one. That's what brainstorming means.

questions.text: The four prescribed conventions (transformation of time, place, character, symbol) work for any style.
questions.explanation: Using prescribed conventions generally did not benefit students as much as using conventions specific to their choice of performance style.
questions.studyTip: Generic conventions = generic marks. Style-specific conventions = higher marks.

questions.text: Conventions should be specific to your chosen performance style rather than relying on the four prescribed conventions.
questions.explanation: Choose conventions that link cleverly to your performance style. Epic theatre? Direct address. Physical theatre? Actors' bodies as primary expression. Know your styles.
questions.studyTip: What conventions define YOUR style? Use those, not the generic four.

questions.text: Writing about character interactions demonstrates understanding of relationships.
questions.explanation: Some students lost sight of the solo performance and stated that both characters appeared together. In solo work, ONE actor plays multiple characters.
questions.studyTip: One actor. Multiple characters. Never 'both characters appeared together.'

questions.text: In solo performance questions, one actor transforms between characters—they never appear simultaneously.
questions.explanation: The actor transforms between characters. You cannot have two characters on stage at once in a solo. Every response must reflect this constraint.
questions.studyTip: Solo = one body. Characters take turns. Transformation is essential.

questions.text: Describing how the actor changes character demonstrates transformation skill.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses applied sophisticated use of drama terminology, particularly the naming of transformation techniques. Name the technique, don't just describe changing.
questions.studyTip: Snap? Morph? Fade? Name the technique. Don't just say 'transformed.'

questions.text: Name specific transformation techniques (snap, morph, fade) rather than just describing character change.
questions.explanation: The expectation was to describe how you complete the transformation technique, not just say a transformation has happened. Name it, then explain the process.
questions.studyTip: Technique name + how it's executed + what expressive skills change.

questions.text: Creating two different characters demonstrates contrast.
questions.explanation: Higher-scoring responses clearly described how the two characters would contrast, integrating contrast within the transformation. Make contrast explicit and visible.
questions.studyTip: Not just different characters—OBVIOUSLY contrasting. Tall/small, fast/slow...

questions.text: Transformation must create distinct contrast between characters through clearly different expressive skills.
questions.explanation: Character 1 might use tall gait, open shoulders, head high. Character 2 uses hunched back, bent knees, head low. The contrast must be specific and physical.
questions.studyTip: List Character 1's skills. List Character 2's. They should be opposites.

questions.text: Any transformation technique works for any transformation question.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring responses got caught up in narrative and transformed place or character when asked about transformation of time. Know which type is being asked for.
questions.studyTip: Time, place, or character? Answer the one they asked for. Not a different one.

questions.text: Read carefully whether the question asks for transformation of time, place, or character—each requires different approach.
questions.explanation: Transformation of time uses mood, rhythm, dramatic elements. Transformation of place changes the space itself. Know what each type requires.
questions.studyTip: Time = when changes. Place = where changes. Character = who changes. Different.

questions.text: Explaining how character would develop shows understanding of improvisation.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring responses described how they would create a character but not how they would use improvisation. Name specific improvisation activities.
questions.studyTip: What's the activity called? What do actors DO in it? Be specific.

questions.text: Describe specific improvisational activities and how they would be used to develop characters or moments.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses described specific improvisational activities and how they would develop character using expressive skills. Keep referring to the activity of improvising.
questions.studyTip: Hot seating? Status games? Physical exploration? Name the activity.

questions.text: Describing expressive skills demonstrates understanding of character development.
questions.explanation: The question required students to consider how improvisation is used in the process of developing character through expressive skills. Both elements must connect.
questions.studyTip: Improvisation activity + expressive skills it develops. Both together.

questions.text: Explain how improvisation activities help actors manipulate expressive skills when developing characters.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses explained how the actor manipulated expressive skills in trialling a character through improvisation. Show the connection between activity and skill development.
questions.studyTip: Through this improvisation, the actor explores voice by... Show the link.

questions.text: Stating that a prop is symbolic demonstrates understanding of symbolism.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring responses simply stated that a prop or costume would be symbolic without discussing what it would represent or how. Explain the symbol AND the manipulation.
questions.studyTip: What does it symbolise? How does the actor USE it? Both needed.

questions.text: Explain what the prop/costume symbolises AND how the actor will manipulate it to communicate meaning.
questions.explanation: Merely wearing a costume is not manipulating it. Explain how the actor works with the prop or costume—movement, transformation, interaction creates symbolic meaning.
questions.studyTip: Wearing ≠ manipulating. How does the actor WORK with the item?

questions.text: Exploring and refining are both development activities that serve similar purposes.
questions.explanation: The focus was on delineating between exploring/trialling ideas and refining them. These are different parts of the process requiring different activities.
questions.studyTip: Exploring tries options. Refining improves chosen options. Different stages.

questions.text: Exploring/trialling tries out possibilities; refining improves and perfects chosen ideas—these require different activities.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses described how one or more exercises could refine an idea previously explored. Refining involves narrowing choices, synchronising timing, improving coordination.
questions.studyTip: Asked to refine? Explain how to make an existing idea BETTER, not try new things.

concepts.title: Distinguish sound as element vs production area

questions.text: Sound can be discussed either as a dramatic element or production area.
questions.explanation: The focus was delineating between sound as a dramatic element and sound design as a production area. These are different things requiring different explanations.
questions.studyTip: Sound element = what actors make. Sound design = technical/recorded sound.

questions.text: Sound as dramatic element (actor-created) is distinct from sound design as production area (technical/recorded).
questions.explanation: Sound as dramatic element includes actors making sounds with bodies, voices, objects. Sound design as production area involves recorded, technical, or amplified sound.
questions.studyTip: Actors clapping = dramatic element. Recorded music = production area.

questions.text: Any relevant production area can be discussed when asked about production areas.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring responses used a production area other than one of those listed. When a question lists specific options, use only those options.
questions.studyTip: Read what's listed. Use only those. Don't substitute your own.

questions.text: When production areas are listed in the question, use only those listed options in your response.
questions.explanation: If the question lists costume, props, sound design—use one of those. Using lighting when it's not listed means your response doesn't address the task.
questions.studyTip: Listed = allowed. Not listed = don't use it. Simple.

questions.text: Any convention can work if applied creatively to any performance style.
questions.explanation: In some cases, conventions were not consistent with the selected performance style. Conventions must match the style you've chosen.
questions.studyTip: Epic theatre = direct address, gestus. Naturalism = fourth wall. Know your style.

questions.text: Conventions must be appropriate to and consistent with your chosen performance style.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses included convention choices that linked cleverly to the performance style. The convention should be recognisable as belonging to that style.
questions.studyTip: Which conventions define your style? Those are the ones to use.

concepts.title: Know main styles and their conventions

questions.text: General knowledge of a few styles is sufficient for the exam.
questions.explanation: The examination assumes students can reference performance styles and their associated conventions with confidence. Revise main performance styles and conventions.
questions.studyTip: Know multiple styles deeply. Each style has specific conventions.

questions.text: You need confident knowledge of main performance styles and their specific associated conventions.
questions.explanation: Build detailed knowledge: Epic theatre, naturalism, absurdism, physical theatre, musical theatre, Australian Gothic, etc. Know what conventions define each.
questions.studyTip: Make a style chart. Style name, key features, conventions. Memorise it.

questions.text: Each part of the question can use different stylistic approaches.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses included choices of performance styles and conventions across the sequence of questions appropriate to the ideas they were exploring.
questions.studyTip: Once you choose a style, stick with it through all parts.

questions.text: Style choices must be consistent across the entire sequence of questions for ensemble or solo devising.
questions.explanation: The examination takes you through a logical progression. Your style choice in part (a) should inform your choices in parts (b), (c), (d), and (e).
questions.studyTip: Choose style carefully at the start. It affects everything after.

questions.text: Answering each part as you reach it shows efficient exam technique.
questions.explanation: Students needed to have read the entire question and corresponding parts carefully BEFORE responding to ensure they could be consistent across all five tasks.
questions.studyTip: Read ALL parts first. Your answer to (a) affects (b), (c), (d), (e).

questions.text: Read all parts of multi-part questions before beginning, to ensure choices remain consistent throughout.
questions.explanation: Judicious choice of stimulus initially allows consistency across all tasks. What you choose in part (a) must still work when you reach part (e).
questions.studyTip: Plan the whole sequence before writing anything. Consistency matters.

concepts.title: Address all aspects of each task

questions.text: A strong response to the main question will compensate for missed minor elements.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring responses inevitably left aspects of the task out. High-scoring responses addressed all aspects of each task, including specific requirements.
questions.studyTip: Every element in the question = something in your answer. Miss nothing.

questions.text: Every element mentioned in the question must be addressed in your response—missing any aspect costs marks.
questions.explanation: Use highlighters to identify different requirements within each question. This helps ensure you address space AND convention AND dramatic element—whatever the question specifies.
questions.studyTip: Highlight each requirement. Check each one off as you address it.

questions.text: Describing your imagined performance in detail shows creative thinking.
questions.explanation: Students need to ensure they don't get so involved in describing the narrative of the imagined performance that they forget to address the specifics of the question.
questions.studyTip: Story detail is not the point. The TASK requirements are the point.

questions.text: Stay focused on task requirements rather than getting absorbed in describing your imagined story.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring responses tended to focus on the narrative at the expense of the specifics of each task. Keep returning to what the question actually asks.
questions.studyTip: Stop. Reread the question. Are you answering IT or telling a story?

questions.text: Spending equal time on all questions ensures thorough coverage.
questions.explanation: Students should prioritise time according to marks allocated. Some students ran out of time and didn't attempt the last parts of Section B.
questions.studyTip: More marks = more time. Don't spend 10 minutes on a 1-mark question.

questions.text: Budget time according to marks—don't spend too long on easy, low-mark questions.
questions.explanation: It is always advantageous to attempt every question. Budget time per question so you don't exhaust yourself on early questions and have nothing left for harder, higher-mark ones.
questions.studyTip: 1 mark = quick answer. 5 marks = detailed answer. Plan accordingly.

questions.text: Continuing answers at the back of the booklet shows thorough responses.
questions.explanation: Students can continue writing on the page below the question lines rather than feel they have to continue at the back. Also, rewriting the question wastes time.
questions.studyTip: Continue below question lines. Don't rewrite the question. Save time.

questions.text: Continue answers in space below question lines; don't waste time rewriting questions.
questions.explanation: Write efficiently. Don't copy out the question. Use available space on the page before going to extra space. Make your writing count.
questions.studyTip: Every word should earn marks. Question copying earns nothing.

questions.text: Explaining what you would brainstorm or script demonstrates understanding.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring responses wrote about brainstorming or scripting rather than doing them. If asked to brainstorm, create a brainstorm. If asked to script, write a script.
questions.studyTip: Don't describe brainstorming. Actually brainstorm. Put ideas on paper.

questions.text: When asked to brainstorm, create an actual brainstorm; when asked to script, write actual script format.
questions.explanation: Brainstorming should use clear and logical mind map layout with plenty of ideas. Scripting should use conventions including stage directions and dialogue.
questions.studyTip: Brainstorm = mind map with many ideas. Script = dialogue + stage directions.

questions.text: Writing character dialogue is sufficient for scripting questions.
questions.explanation: High-scoring scripting responses used the conventions of scripting, including stage directions AND dialogue. Both elements are needed for proper script format.
questions.studyTip: Character name: Dialogue. (Stage directions in brackets.) Both needed.

questions.text: Scripting must include both dialogue AND stage directions in proper script format.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring responses described the scene rather than writing a script. Use proper format: character names, colons, dialogue, and stage directions in brackets or italics.
questions.studyTip: Look at a real script. Copy that format exactly.

questions.text: A strong scene demonstrates understanding regardless of its position in the performance.
questions.explanation: Lower-scoring responses tended not to complete all aspects of the task, particularly appearing to forget it was the opening scene. Position matters.
questions.studyTip: Opening = engages audience, establishes context. Closing = resolves, final impact.

questions.text: If asked about an opening scene, convey a clear sense of engaging an audience; if closing, show resolution or final impact.
questions.explanation: High-scoring responses conveyed a clear sense of this being an opening scene to engage an audience. The position of the moment affects how you should approach it.
questions.studyTip: What makes an OPENING work? What makes a CLOSING work? Different things.
